questions.text:
A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 10 hours after ingesting approximately 40 tablets of aspirin. He is dizzy and nauseated but has not vomited. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 105/66 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild epigastric tenderness. Mental status examination shows confusion. He is oriented to person but not to time or place. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L and a chloride concentration of 103 mEq/L. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?



pH
PaCO2 (mm Hg)
HCO3- (mEq/L)



A
7.43
30
19


B
7.46
48
33


C
7.41
42
26


D
7.55
31
26


E
7.36
50
27


F
7.22
50
20


G
7.44
47
31
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The time that has elapsed since aspirin ingestion indicates that the patient would have both HAGMA and respiratory alkalosis. A low HCO3- concentration is consistent with metabolic acidosis and an anion gap that is expectedly high (18 mEq/L) is obtained when using the measured Na+ and Cl- concentrations and an HCO3- concentration of 19 mEq/L. For a patient with metabolic acidosis, the Winter formula, i.e., expected PaCO2 = (1.5 x HCO3-) + 8 (+/- 2), is used to estimate the expected change in PaCO2 by physiological compensation alone. In order to be consistent with an additional respiratory alkalosis, the measured PaCO2 must be less than the expected PaCO2. For an HCO3- concentration of 19 mEq/L, a measured PaCO2 of 30 mm Hg is lower than the expected PaCO2 (34.5–38.5 mm Hg) and is therefore consistent with the expected findings. In patients with mixed acidosis and alkalosis, the pH can be normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Alkalemia with a high PaCO2 (48 mm Hg) indicates a metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic alkalosis can occur in patients with aspirin toxicity as a result of severe vomiting. However, this patient has not vomited following aspirin ingestion.

C) INCORRECT:

This set of arterial blood gas findings is normal. This patient, who has manifestations of the late phase of aspirin toxicity, is unlikely to have normal arterial blood gas findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Alkalemia with low PaCO2 (31 mm Hg), normal bicarbonate (26 mEq/L), and a normal anion gap (11 mEq/L) indicates a noncompensated respiratory alkalosis. Respiratory alkalosis develops in the early phase of salicylate toxicity. However, several hours after salicylate ingestion, patients also develop a high anion gap metabolic acidosis that results in a mixed acid-base disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

A normal pH (7.36) with high PaCO2 (50 mm Hg), normal bicarbonate (27 mEq/L), and a normal anion gap (10 mEq/L) indicates a noncompensated respiratory acidosis. This patient, who is hyperventilating, is unlikely to have a respiratory acidosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Acidemia with high PaCO2 (50 mm Hg), low bicarbonate (20 mEq/L), and a high anion gap (17 mEq/L) indicates a respiratory acidosis with an additional high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA). Patients with salicylate poisoning usually develop a HAGMA due to the accumulation of lactic acid, organic ketoacids, and salicylate. Occasionally, respiratory acidosis can occur with severe salicylate toxicity as a result of CNS depression and hypoventilation. However, this patient, who is hyperventilating, is unlikely to have a respiratory acidosis.

G) INCORRECT:

A normal pH of 7.44 with high PaCO2 (47 mm Hg), high bicarbonate (31 mEq/L), and a normal anion gap (6 mEq/L) indicates a combination of metabolic alkalosis and respiratory acidosis. Another mixed acid-base disorder should be suspected in patients with salicylate overdose.
questions.hint: In the early phase of aspirin toxicity, patients develop respiratory alkalosis as a result of hyperventilation (due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center in the medulla by salicylate). In the late phase, which occurs several hours after ingestion, patients develop an additional high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) primarily because salicylate uncouples mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation and increases the conversion of acetyl-CoA and pyruvate to ketoacids and lactate respectively.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man with early Alzheimer-related dementia presents with his son for evaluation of nausea and worsening confusion during the past 4 days. He has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and chronic low back pain. His current medications are aspirin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. He lives alone in an assisted living facility, where a nurse checks on him weekly and assists with his medications. The nurse’s last visit was 4 days ago, when the patient was feeling well.
On examination, he has a blood pressure of 105/61 mm Hg, a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 37.7°C. He is confused, restless, and oriented only to self. Extraocular movements are normal. Oral mucosa and skin are dry. Examination of the heart, lungs, and abdomen is within normal limits, and his gait is normal.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.5
13.5–17.5


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
9000
4500–11,000


Platelet count (per mm3)
100,000
150,000–350,000


Sodium (mEq/liter)
146
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
3.2
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
106
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
17
21–30


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
28
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.1
0.8–1.3


Lactate (mmol/liter)
4.6
0.6–1.7


Fasting glucose (mg/dL)
91
70–100


pH
7.43
7.38–7.44


Partial pressure of oxygen (mm Hg)
99
80–100


Partial pressure of carbon dioxide (mm Hg)
26
35–45


Routine urinalysis is normal.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings?

choices.text: Urine culture from straight catheterization sample
Lumbar puncture and cerebrospinal fluid analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urinary tract infection in older patients may manifest with confusion and lactic acidosis; however, this diagnosis is unlikely in the setting of normal urinalysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Meningitis and meningoencephalitis are less likely diagnoses in this patient, who has no fever or leukocytosis. Lumbar puncture would not be the most appropriate first step in a patient who has classic signs and symptoms of salicylate poisoning.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with worsening confusion, gastrointestinal symptoms, and a mixed acid-base disturbance with evidence of both a primary respiratory alkalosis and an anion-gap metabolic acidosis.

Understanding the Acid-Base Disorder in This Case

This patient’s pH is elevated, whereas both his plasma bicarbonate and partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) are low. These findings are consistent with a respiratory alkalosis, as the pH should not be elevated with the respiratory compensation for a metabolic acidosis. (In a metabolic acidosis, the respiratory system does not overcompensate but instead increases ventilation to bring the pH toward normal.) In addition, the anion gap is elevated, consistent with an underlying metabolic acidosis. The anion gap is calculated by subtracting the major anions in the blood from the major cation, sodium. In this case, it is 146 - (106 + 17) = 23.

Another strategy to assess the acid-base disorder is to determine the predicted PaCO2 based on the bicarbonate (HCO3) level using the Winters formula: predicted PaCO2 = 1.5 x HCO3- + 8 ± 2. In this case, the predicted PaCO2 is 1.5 x 17 + 8 ± 2 = 33 ± 2, but the observed PaCO2 (26) is much lower. This finding is unexpected and consistent with an additional respiratory alkalosis.

The most likely cause of this constellation of findings is salicylate poisoning. This patient has access to aspirin, and accidental overdose is possible given his cognitive impairment. His salicylate level should be measured to confirm the diagnosis.

The manifestations of salicylate poisoning depend on the severity and acuity of the poisoning. Classically, patients have respiratory alkalosis (related to stimulation of the respiratory center) along with gastrointestinal irritation and tinnitus. More-severe cases may manifest with altered mental status, seizures, and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema. Laboratory studies may show hypokalemia, metabolic acidosis with increased anion gap, and an elevated lactate level. Young children and older patients may develop chronic salicylate poisoning with less-pronounced symptoms. Rapid recognition and treatment is critical to reduce risk for further clinical deterioration and death.

Other Considerations in This Case

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can cause the acute onset of Wernicke encephalopathy, which typically includes findings of ataxia and nystagmus along with confusion. This diagnosis is a clinical one that requires a high index of suspicion. When it is being considered, prompt thiamine replacement is indicated. Thiamine can be measured, but the sensitivity and specificity of the test is unknown. In addition, thiamine deficiency does not cause a respiratory alkalosis, although it can cause elevated lactate levels in the setting of beriberi.

Serum osmolality should be measured in patients with an anion-gap metabolic acidosis, given that ingestion of certain substances, such as methanol and ethylene glycol, can cause a metabolic acidosis and an osmolal gap. However, these poisonings do not cause a respiratory alkalosis and thus would not explain this patient's constellation of findings.

Key learning point: The drug intoxication most likely to cause a mixed acid-base disturbance of respiratory alkalosis and anion-gap metabolic acidosis is salicylate (aspirin).

D) INCORRECT:

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency can cause the acute onset of Wernicke encephalopathy, which typically includes findings of ataxia and nystagmus along with confusion. This diagnosis is a clinical one that requires a high index of suspicion. When it is being considered, prompt thiamine replacement is indicated. Thiamine can be measured, but the sensitivity and specificity of the test is unknown. In addition, thiamine deficiency does not cause a respiratory alkalosis, although it can cause elevated lactate levels in the setting of beriberi.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum osmolality should be measured in patients with an anion-gap metabolic acidosis, given that ingestion of certain substances, such as methanol and ethylene glycol, can cause a metabolic acidosis and an osmolal gap. However, these poisonings do not cause a respiratory alkalosis and thus would not explain this patient's constellation of findings.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents 45 minutes after ingesting a large number of antihistamine tablets. He is stable and alert. What is the most appropriate initial intervention to limit toxin absorption?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastric lavage is reserved for life-threatening ingestions due to risks like aspiration and mucosal injury. In stable patients, its risk-benefit profile is unfavorable. Additionally, tablet dissolution limits lavage efficacy. The patient's stable condition and the invasive nature of lavage make it unsuitable.

B) INCORRECT:

N-acetylcysteine is an antidote for acetaminophen overdose, replenishing hepatic glutathione. Antihistamines do not produce a glutathione-depleting metabolite. The patient's stable condition suggests strategies to limit gastrointestinal absorption, not systemic metabolism alteration, are appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Urgent hemodialysis is effective for toxins with low molecular weight, minimal protein binding, and small volume of distribution. Antihistamines have high protein binding and large volume of distribution, reducing hemodialysis effectiveness. The patient's stable condition suggests limiting gastrointestinal absorption is the priority, making activated charcoal more appropriate.

D) CORRECT:

Activated charcoal adsorbs ingested toxins in the gastrointestinal tract, reducing systemic absorption. Administered within 1 to 2 hours of ingestion, it binds substances like antihistamines, limiting their bioavailability and toxic effects. This approach is effective soon after ingestion, especially when the patient is stable and alert, as it interrupts further absorption without invasive procedures. Activated charcoal is a cornerstone in managing toxic ingestions due to its efficacy in adsorbing a wide range of substances.

Key learning point: Activated charcoal is the preferred initial management for many cases of toxic ingestion to prevent further absorption of the toxin.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with tinnitus and rapid breathing after ingesting aspirin has acute respiratory alkalosis on ABG. Which additional acid-base disturbance is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Respiratory acidosis results from hypoventilation and CO2 retention. In aspirin toxicity, hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis. The patient's tachypnea and respiratory alkalosis are inconsistent with respiratory acidosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Metabolic alkalosis involves a primary gain in bicarbonate or loss of hydrogen ions, seen in conditions like vomiting or diuretic use. Aspirin toxicity causes respiratory alkalosis and high anion gap metabolic acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis arises from bicarbonate loss with chloride retention, such as in gastrointestinal bicarbonate loss or renal tubular acidosis. In aspirin toxicity, the metabolic acidosis is due to organic acid accumulation, resulting in a high anion gap, not a normal anion gap.

D) CORRECT:

Aspirin overdose leads to a mixed acid-base disorder. Initially, salicylates stimulate the medullary respiratory center, causing hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis. As toxicity progresses, impaired cellular metabolism results in the accumulation of organic acids like lactic acid and ketoacids, leading to high anion gap metabolic acidosis. This biphasic pattern of initial respiratory alkalosis followed by high anion gap metabolic acidosis is characteristic of salicylate toxicity.

Key learning point: Aspirin overdose typically causes an initial respiratory alkalosis due to hyperventilation, followed by a metabolic acidosis as salicylic acid accumulates.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-hour history of nausea, vomiting, and restlessness. Her family reports she has been taking multiple over-the-counter medications for chronic pain and reported ringing in her ears earlier today. She appears agitated and is hyperventilating. Vital signs are T, 38.6°C (101.5°F); P, 115; R, 34; BP, 138/85; oxygen saturation, 99% on room air. Laboratory studies show pH 7.35, PCO2 25 mm Hg, HCO3- 14 mEq/L, glucose 108 mg/dL, and anion gap 24 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with a mixed acid-base disorder (respiratory alkalosis with metabolic acidosis), tinnitus, a high anion gap, agitation and hyperthermia, which suggest salicylate poisoning. The PCO2 of 25 is lower than expected (∼ 29) for pure respiratory compensation, indicating concurrent respiratory alkalosis from direct CNS stimulation. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate for serum and urine alkalinization is the most appropriate initial management to achieve target serum pH 7.45–7.55 and urine pH 7.5–8.0.

B) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal may be considered for gastrointestinal decontamination but is not the most appropriate initial step in management. This patient is agitated, which could compromise her airway during charcoal administration, and another step is more appropriate to manage systemic toxicity and prevent further cellular uptake of salicylates.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis may be indicated in severe salicylate poisoning. However, this patient presents with agitation and restlessness, and therefore does not meet the criteria for immediate dialysis (severe altered mental status such as coma or seizures, salicylate levels > 100 mg/dL, or new hypoxemia requiring supplemental oxygen). Another step in management is indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Thiamine is used to treat suspected thiamine deficiency or Wernicke encephalopathy, typically in malnourished patients and/or those with alcohol use disorder. This patient presents with tinnitus, mixed acid-base disorder, hyperthermia, and a high anion gap, which are characteristic of salicylate poisoning rather than thiamine deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Endotracheal intubation should be avoided in salicylate poisoning unless absolutely necessary. Compensatory hyperventilation is critical for managing metabolic acidosis, and patients may rapidly decompensate if their ventilation needs are not met after intubation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman with a history of major depressive disorder is brought to the emergency department by her roommate for altered mental status. The roommate found an empty bottle of aspirin next to her. The patient is agitated, confused, and reports ringing in her ears. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis but is otherwise unremarkable. An arterial blood gas (ABG) and a basic metabolic panel are obtained. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of this patient's condition?

choices.text: pH: 7.52, PCO2: 48 mm Hg, HCO3-: 35 mEq/L
pH: 7.44, PCO2: 20 mm Hg, HCO3-: 12 mEq/L
pH: 7.20, PCO2: 65 mm Hg, HCO3-: 26 mEq/L
pH: 7.25, PCO2: 28 mm Hg, HCO3-: 10 mEq/L
pH: 7.55, PCO2: 25 mm Hg, HCO3-: 23 mEq/L

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This ABG indicates a primary metabolic alkalosis. This finding is not consistent with the pathophysiology of salicylate toxicity, which involves the accumulation of organic acids and direct stimulation of the respiratory drive. Causes of metabolic alkalosis include vomiting, diuretic use, or mineralocorticoid excess, none of which are suggested by the clinical scenario.

B) CORRECT:

This ABG demonstrates the hallmark acid-base disturbance of salicylate toxicity: a mixed primary respiratory alkalosis and anion gap metabolic acidosis. Salicylates directly stimulate the medullary respiratory center, causing hyperventilation (tachypnea) and a primary respiratory alkalosis (low PCO2). Concurrently, they uncouple oxidative phosphorylation, leading to anaerobic metabolism and the accumulation of organic acids like lactate and ketoacids, resulting in a primary metabolic acidosis (low HCO3‑). The pH is often near normal because the two primary disorders have opposing effects. This patient's clinical presentation of tinnitus, fever, tachypnea, and altered mental status strongly supports this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

This ABG indicates a primary respiratory acidosis. This finding is inconsistent with salicylate toxicity, which causes respiratory stimulation and tachypnea, leading to a low PCO2. Respiratory acidosis would be seen only in the pre-terminal phase of a severe overdose due to central nervous system depression or respiratory muscle fatigue, not as the characteristic initial finding.

D) INCORRECT:

This ABG shows a primary metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation. Although salicylate toxicity causes a metabolic acidosis, this pattern does not reflect the primary respiratory stimulation that is also characteristic of the poisoning. In classic salicylate toxicity, the PCO2 is typically lower than what would be expected from compensation alone because hyperventilation is also a primary process.

E) INCORRECT:

This ABG shows a primary respiratory alkalosis with minimal metabolic compensation. This pattern can be seen in the very early stages of salicylate toxicity due to initial stimulation of the respiratory center. However, this patient's significant symptoms, including fever and altered mental status, suggest that the metabolic acidosis component has already developed, making this isolated finding less likely.
questions.hint: Salicylate toxicity classically causes a mixed acid-base disorder by directly stimulating the medullary respiratory center and simultaneously uncoupling oxidative phosphorylation.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police because of altered mental status. The police found him covering his ears and shouting near a highway rest area. Upon questioning, he was unable to look directly at the police and answer coherently. On the way to the hospital, he reported feeling nauseous and vomited twice. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 110/77 mm Hg. He is admitted to the hospital for evaluation. Three hours after admission, he has a tonic-clonic seizure. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Na+

140 mEq/L


Cl-

102 mEq/L


Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:



On admission
Three hours later


pH
7.47
7.39


PaCO2
24 mm Hg
31 mm Hg


PO2

84 mm Hg
82 mm Hg


HCO3-
20 mEq/L
18 mEq/L


Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Opioid overdose may manifest with altered mental status and seizures, as seen here. However, it does not manifest with tachypnea and respiratory alkalosis, but with respiratory acidosis secondary to respiratory depression. Opioid overdose does not cause a mixed acid-base disorder and is associated with additional symptoms such as bilateral miosis, bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia, all of which are absent in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Salicylate toxicity from overdose with aspirin is the most likely explanation for this patient's presentation. In early toxicity, salicylates directly stimulate the medullary respiratory center and cause tachypnea and hyperpnea, both of which manifest with respiratory alkalosis. Later, the accumulation of organic acids (due to salicylates inhibiting citric acid cycle enzymes) causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis, which leads to a mixed acid-base disorder. Features of salicylate toxicity include tinnitus, nausea, vomiting, mental status changes, hyperthermia (due to uncoupling of mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation), pulmonary edema, seizures, and, ultimately, coma.

C) INCORRECT:

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) may manifest with altered mental status, seizures, nausea, vomiting, tachypnea, and high anion gap metabolic acidosis, as in this patient. However, DKA is not associated with a mixed acid-base disorder; instead, appropriate respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis would be seen (resulting in Kussmaul breathing). Furthermore, DKA typically presents with additional symptoms such as polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, signs of volume depletion, abdominal pain, and fruity odor of the breath, none of which are observed in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Recurrent vomiting can cause a significant loss of HCl, NaCl, and KCl, leading to a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, which can be further aggravated by hypovolemia (contraction alkalosis). This patient shows no loss of chloride and vomiting would not explain this patient's initial respiratory alkalosis or high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute adrenal insufficiency may manifest with impaired consciousness, fever, and vomiting, as observed in this patient. However, additional symptoms would include hypotension/shock and severe abdominal pain. Typical laboratory findings of acute adrenal insufficiency are hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, none of which are present here. Finally, acute adrenal insufficiency is not associated with a mixed acid-base disorder; instead, appropriate respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis would be seen.
questions.hint: This patient initially had respiratory alkalosis on admission. The significant decrease in pH in combination with the decrease in HCO3- and an elevated anion gap (20 mEq/L) three hours later suggests metabolic acidosis. Since this patient's PaCO2 (31 mm Hg) is lower than would be expected from normal respiratory compensation of metabolic acidosis (35 mm Hg ± 2 according to Winter's formula), this patient most likely has a mixed acid-base disorder.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by the police because of altered mental status. The police found him covering his ears and shouting near a highway rest area. On the way to the hospital, he reported feeling nauseous and vomited twice. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 110/77 mm Hg. He is admitted to the hospital for evaluation. Three hours after admission, he has a tonic-clonic seizure. The patient's serum sodium is 140 mEq/L and chloride is 102 mEq/L. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air:



On admission
Three hours later


pH
7.47
7.39


PaCO2
24 mm Hg
31 mm Hg


PO2

84 mm Hg
82 mm Hg


HCO3-
20 mEq/L
18 mEq/L


Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's laboratory findings?

A) INCORRECT:

Opioid overdose may manifest with altered mental status and seizures, as seen here. Finally, acute adrenal insufficiency is not associated with a mixed acid-base disorder; instead, appropriate respiratory compensation for metabolic acidosis would be seen.

The significant decrease in pH in combination with the decrease in HCO3- and an elevated anion gap (20 mEq/L) three hours later suggests metabolic acidosis. Since this patient's PaCO2 (31 mm Hg) is lower than would be expected from normal respiratory compensation of metabolic acidosis (35 mm Hg ± 2 according to Winter's formula), this patient most likely has a mixed acid-base disorder.
